keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, was sentenced to five years to life in prison for raping two women in northern Utah in 2008, after being identified through a DNA rape kit and fleeing the U.S. to evade arrest.

Rossi appeared to fake his death in 2020 by an online obituary claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which authorities later disproved; he had actually fled to Scotland, where he was arrested while receiving treatment for COVID-19.
Rossi used multiple aliases over the years, including 'Arthur Knight,' and was previously wanted in Rhode Island for failing to register as a sex offender.
In both cases, the victims came forward years later, with the first victim having been engaged to Rossi and the second having gone to collect stolen money from him.
The case highlights the importance of addressing rape kit backlogs, the dangers of false death claims by fugitives, and the role of DNA databases in solving cold cases.
Utah law allows sentencing ranges, and for first-degree rape, the range is five years to life; Rossi’s sentence falls within that range, with parole eligibility determined by a parole board.
Rossi maintained his innocence in court, claiming the victims were lying, and did not testify during trial, while prosecutors emphasized he was a flight risk and a serial abuser.
The victim described the trauma of the assault and called for accountability and safety, emphasizing the long-term psychological damage of such crimes.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Utah judge sentenced Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, to five years to life in prison for raping two women in northern Utah in 2008. Rossi, identified through a decade-old DNA rape kit, had allegedly faked his death by claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma in 2020, prompting authorities to search for him. He fled to Scotland, where he was arrested while receiving treatment for COVID-19 due to distinctive tattoos, and later extradited to Utah in 2024. Prosecutors portrayed him as a flight risk and serial abuser, while Rossi maintained his innocence and claimed the victims were lying. The case underscores the importance of addressing rape kit backlogs, the dangers of false death claims, and international cooperation in tracking fugitives. Rossi is scheduled for sentencing in November for a second conviction, and a parole board will determine his release date.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
